DOC.HEAD: Hotel Officials Pressing U.S. Government for Protection
Eds: CORRECTS spelling to Conner sted Connor in grafs 4, The remainder, and 8, Conner said
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the Marriott Corp. said today they were pressing the U.S. government to ensure the safety of guests at a luxury hotel in downtown Panama City after several people were taken from the building by Panamanian troops. The 400-room Marriott Hotel, which employs 300 people, was about 42 perce Tuesday when Panamanian military troops came to the facility, according to Roger Conner, a spokesman for Betent occupied lathesda, Md.-based Marriott. Although Conner said details were sketchy, it was his understanding that ``Panamanian military forces had come into our hotel and seized an undetermined amount of people.'' He said a handful of journalists, as well as several employees, were taken from the hotel early this morning by Panamanian troops. The remainder of the guests were accommodated in the hotel ballroom, Conner said. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said U.S. forces in Panama were aware of hostages taken from the Marriott Hotel and that some Americans were still at liberty in the building. ``We will make efforts to take care of that,'' said Williams. But he declined to say whether American troops were moving guests in a situation that was ``just like when an earthquake hits ... Everyone makes do.'' ``Operations are not normal,'' he said, but he did not think the hotel guests were under guard by Panamanian military officials. The hotel's general manager, Sapinder Palta, was at a meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., today but had been in touch with the hotel by telephone, Conner said. Other hotel officials, including Marriott Hotels President Bill Tiesel, were trying to get through to the hotel, but having little success, Conner said. But the hotel officials had been in touch with the U.S. government. ``From Marriott's standpoint, we are taking every effort to have the U.S. military troops secure the hotel so that guests can be protected,'' he said. The hotel, the Panama Marriott Caesar Park, is owned by Aoki Construction Inc., a Japanese company, but it is managed by Marriott. Opened in 1982, the hotel is adjacent to the Atlapa Convention Center five minutes from the banking center of Panama City. At the time of the U.S. invasion of Panama, most of the guests were journalists and airline crews, Conner said. There were few businessmen in the hotel, he said.
